title: Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Iraq Region
text:
The Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Iraq Region ( "Ḥizb al-Ba‘th al-'Arabī al-Ishtirākī fī al-'Irāq"), officially the Iraqi Regional Branch, is an <a href="Iraq">Iraq</a>i <a href="Ba%27athism">Ba'athist</a> <a href="political%20party">political party</a> founded in 1951 by <a href="Fuad%20al-Rikabi">Fuad al-Rikabi</a>. It was the Iraqi regional branch of the <a href="Ba%27ath%20Party">original Ba'ath Party</a> before changing its allegiance to the <a href="Ba%27ath%20Party%20%28Iraqi-dominated%20faction%29">Iraqi-dominated Ba'ath movement</a> following the <a href="1966%20Syrian%20coup%20d%27%C3%A9tat">1966 split</a> within the original party. The party was officially banned following the <a href="2003%20invasion%20of%20Iraq">American invasion of Iraq</a> in 2003, but despite this it still continues to function underground.
History.
Early years and 14 July Revolution: 1951–1958.
The Iraqi Regional Branch of the Ba'ath Party was established in 1951 or 1952. Some historians claim that the Iraqi Regional Branch was established by Abd ar Rahman ad Damin and Abd al Khaliq al Khudayri in 1947 after their return from the founding congress of the Ba'ath Party held in <a href="Damascus">Damascus</a>, <a href="Syria">Syria</a> the same year. In another version, <a href="Fuad%20al-Rikabi">Fuad al-Rikabi</a> established the Iraqi Regional Branch in 1948 with Sa'dun Hamadi, a <a href="Shia%20Islam">Shia</a> <a href="Muslim">Muslim</a>, but became secretary of the <a href="Regional%20Command%20of%20the%20Arab%20Socialist%20Ba%27ath%20Party%20%E2%80%93%20Iraq%20Region">Regional Command</a> in 1952.
The Iraqi Regional Branch was <a href="Arab%20nationalism">Arab nationalist</a> and vague in its socialist orientation. Al-Rikabi, expelled from the party in 1961 for being a <a href="Nasserism">Nasserist</a>, was an early follower of <a href="Michel%20Aflaq">Michel Aflaq</a>, the founder of <a href="Ba%27athism">Ba'athism</a>. During the party's early days, members discussed topics regarding Arab nationalism, the <a href="Social%20inequality">social inequalities</a> that had grown out of the British "<a href="Tribal%20Criminal%20and%20Civil%20Disputes%20Regulation">Tribal Criminal and Civil Disputes Regulation</a>," and the <a href="Council%20of%20Representatives%20of%20Iraq">Iraqi Parliament's</a> Law 28 of 1932 "Governing the Rights and Duties of Cultivators". By 1953, the party, led by al-Rikabi, was engaged in <a href="Subversion">subversive</a> activities against the government.
The party initially consisted of a majority of Shia Muslims, as al-Rikabi primarily recruited his friends and family, but it slowly became <a href="Sunni%20Islam">Sunni</a>-dominated. The Ba'ath Party, and others of <a href="Pan-Arabism">pan-Arab</a> orientation, found it increasingly difficult to recruit Shia members within the party organisation. Most Shias saw pan-Arab as largely Sunni, since most <a href="Arabs">Arabs</a> are Sunni. As a result, more Shias joined the <a href="Iraqi%20Communist%20Party">Iraqi Communist Party</a> than the Ba'ath Party. In the mid-1950s, eight of 17 members of the Ba'ath leadership were Shia.
According to <a href="Talib%20El-Shibib">Talib El-Shibib</a>, the Ba'ath foreign minister in the <a href="Ahmed%20Hassan%20al-Bakr">Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr</a> government, the sectarian background of the leading Ba'ath members was considered of little importance because most Ba'athists did not know each other's <a href="sect">sect</a>arian <a href="Religious%20denomination">denominations</a>. Between 1952 and 1963, 54% of the members of the Ba'ath Regional Command were Shia Muslims, largely because of al-Rikabi's effective recruitment drive in Shia areas. Between 1963 and 1970, after al-Rikabi's resignation, Shia representation in the Regional Command had fallen to 14 percent. However, of the three factions within the Ba'ath Party, two out of three <a href="Political%20faction">faction</a> leaders were Shia.
By the end of 1951, the party had at least 50 members. With the collapse of the pan-Arabist <a href="United%20Arab%20Republic">United Arab Republic</a> (UAR), several leading Ba'ath members, including al-Rikabi, resigned from the party in protest. In 1958, the year of the <a href="14%20July%20Revolution">14 July Revolution</a> that overthrew the <a href="Hashemites">Hashemite</a> <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Iraq">monarchy</a>, the Ba'ath Party had 300 members nationwide. General <a href="Abd%20al-Karim%20Qasim">Abd al-Karim Qasim</a>, the leader of the Free Officers Movement which overthrew the <a href="Faisal%20II%20of%20Iraq">king</a>, supported joining the UAR, but changed his position when he took power. Several members of the Free Officer Movement were also members of the Ba'ath Party. The Ba'ath Party considered the President of Egypt <a href="Gamal%20Abdel%20Nasser">Gamal Abdel Nasser</a>, the leader of the pan-Arab movement, to be the leader most likely to succeed, and supported Iraq's joining the union. Of the 16 members of Qasim's cabinet, 12 were Ba'ath Party members. However, the Ba'ath Party supported Qasim on the grounds that he would join Nasser's UAR.
Qasim's Iraq: 1958–1963.
Shortly after taking power, Qasim changed his position on joining the UAR and started campaigning for the "Iraq first policy". To strengthen his own position within the government, Qasim created an alliance with the <a href="Iraqi%20Communist%20Party">Iraqi Communist Party</a>, which was opposed to the notion of pan-Arabism. The change of policy provoked several pan-Arab organisations, especially the Ba'ath Party. Later that year, the Ba'ath Party leadership was planning to assassinate Qasim and take power to continue the policy of pan-Arabism.
<a href="Saddam%20Hussein">Saddam Hussein</a> was a member of the operation. At the time, the Ba'ath Party was more of an ideological experiment than a strong, anti-government, fighting machine. Most of its members were either educated professionals or students, and Saddam Hussein fit the bill. Abdul Karim al-Shaikhly, the leader of the operation, asked Hussein to join it when one of the team members left. The idea of assassinating Qasim may have been Nasser's and speculations exist that some participants in the operation received training in Damascus, which was then part of the UAR. However, "no evidence has ever been produced to implicate Nasser directly in the plot."
The assassins planned to <a href="ambush">ambush</a> Qasim at Al-Rashid Street on 7 October 1959. One man was to kill those sitting in the back of the car, the rest would kill those in front. During the ambush, Hussein began shooting prematurely, which disorganised the whole operation. Qasim's chauffeur was killed and Qasim was hit in the arm and shoulder. The assassins thought they had killed him and quickly retreated to their headquarters, but Qasim survived.
At the time of the attack, the Ba'ath Party had less than 1,000 members. Some of the plotters quickly left the country for Syria, where <a href="Michel%20Aflaq">Michel Aflaq</a> gave Hussein full party membership. The Iraqi government arrested some members of the operation and took them into custody. At the <a href="show%20trial">show trial</a>, six of the defendants were sentenced to death and, for unknown reasons, the sentences were not carried out. Aflaq, the leader of the Ba'athist movement, organised the expulsion of leading Iraqi Ba'athist members, such as <a href="Fuad%20al-Rikabi">Fuad al-Rikabi</a>, on the grounds that the party should not have initiated the attempt on Qasim's life. At the same time, Aflaq secured seats in the Iraqi Ba'ath leadership for his supporters, including Hussein.
Qasim was overthrown in the <a href="Ramadan%20Revolution">Ramadan Revolution</a> in February 1963, which was allegedly supported by the U.S. <a href="Central%20Intelligence%20Agency">Central Intelligence Agency</a> (CIA) and led on the ground by <a href="Ahmed%20Hassan%20al-Bakr">Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr</a>. Declassified documents and the testimony of former CIA officers indicate there was no direct American involvement, although the CIA had been previously notified of an earlier Ba'athist coup plot in July 1962 by a high-ranking informant within the Party. The CIA official working with <a href="Archibald%20Bulloch%20Roosevelt%20Jr.">Archie Roosevelt, Jr.</a> on a separate plan to instigate a military coup against Qasim, and who later became the head of the CIA's operations in Iraq and Syria "from late 1968 to June 1970," has "denied any involvement in the Ba'ath Party's actions," stating instead that the CIA's efforts against Qasim were still in the planning stages at the time. Several army units refused to support the Ba'athist coup. The fighting lasted for two days, during which 1,500–5,000 were killed. Qasim was captured and, an hour later, he was <a href="Execution%20by%20firing%20squad">killed by firing squad</a>. To assure the Iraqi public that Qasim was dead, the plotters broadcast a film of Qasim's corpse being mutilated.
In power: February–September 1963.
<a href="Abdul%20Salam%20Arif">Abdul Salam Arif</a> became the president of Iraq and <a href="Ahmed%20Hassan%20al-Bakr">Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr</a> became <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Iraq">prime minister</a>. Ali Salih al-Sadi, secretary-general of the Regional Command of the Iraqi Ba'ath Party, became <a href="deputy%20prime%20minister">deputy prime minister</a> and <a href="Ministry%20of%20Interior%20%28Iraq%29">Minister of Interior</a>a post he lost on 11 May. Despite not being prime minister, al-Sadi had effective control over the Iraqi Ba'ath Party. Seven out of nine members supported his leadership in the party's Regional Command.
According to Coughlin, in the aftermath of the coup, the <a href="National%20Guard%20%28Iraq%29">National Guard</a> initiated an "orgy of violence" against all communist elements and some <a href="Left-wing%20politics">left-wing</a> forces. This period led to the establishment in Baghdad of several interrogation chambers. The government requisitioned several private houses and public facilities, and an entire section of Kifah Street was used by the National Guard. Many of the victims of the <a href="rout">rout</a> were innocent, or were victims of personal <a href="Feud">vendettas</a>. According to Coughlin, the most notorious <a href="torture%20chamber">torture chamber</a> was located at the "Palace of the End," where the royal family was killed in 1958. Nadhim Kazzer, who became director of the <a href="Directorate%20of%20General%20Security">Directorate of General Security</a>, was responsible for the acts committed there.
The party was <a href="November%201963%20Iraqi%20coup%20d%27%C3%A9tat">ousted</a> from government in November 1963, due to factionalism. The question within the Ba'ath Party was whether or not it would pursue its ideological goal of establishing a union with Syria, <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a> or both. Al-Sadi supported a union with Syria, which was ruled by the Ba'ath Party, while the more conservative military wing supported Qasim's "Iraq first policy". Factionalism and the ill-disciplined behaviour of the National Guard led the military wing to initiate a coup against the party's leadership. Al-Sadi was forced into exile in <a href="Spain">Spain</a>.
Al-Bakr, in an attempt to save the party, called for a meeting of the <a href="National%20Command%20of%20the%20Ba%27ath%20Party">National Command of the Ba'ath Party</a>. The meeting exacerbated the party's problems. Aflaq, who saw himself as the leader of the pan-Arab Ba'athist movement, declared his intent to take control of the Iraqi Ba'ath Party. The "Iraq first" wing was outraged. President Arif lost patience with the Iraqi Ba'ath Party, and the party was ousted from government on 18 November 1963. The 12 Ba'ath members of the government were forced to resign, and the National Guard was dissolved and replaced with the <a href="Republican%20Guard%20%28Iraq%29">Republican Guard</a>. Some authorities believe that Aflaq supported Arif's coup against the Ba'athist government in order to weaken al-Sadi's position within the party and strengthen his own.
Union talks with Syria.
At the time of al-Sadi's removal from the post of Interior Minister, factionalism and discontent were growing within the party. al-Sadi and Mundur al-Windawi, the leader of the Ba'ath Party's National Guard, led the civilian wing. President Arif led the military wing and <a href="Talib%20El-Shibib">Talib El-Shibib</a> led the pro-Aflaq wing. However, a bigger schism was underway in the international Ba'athist movement. Four major factions were being created: the Old Guard led by Aflaq; a civilian alliance between the secretary-generals of the Regional Commands of Syria and Iraq, led by <a href="Hammud%20al-Shufi">Hammud al-Shufi</a> and al-Sadi respectively; the Syrian Ba'ath Military Committee, represented by <a href="Salah%20Jadid">Salah Jadid</a>, <a href="Muhammad%20Umran">Muhammad Umran</a>, <a href="Hafez%20al-Assad">Hafez al-Assad</a>, <a href="Salim%20Hatum">Salim Hatum</a> and <a href="Amin%20al-Hafiz">Amin al-Hafiz</a>; and the Iraqi military wing, which supported Arif's presidency, represented by al-Bakr, <a href="Salih%20Mahdi%20Ammash">Salih Mahdi Ammash</a>, <a href="Tahir%20Yahya">Tahir Yahya</a> and Hardan Tikriti. The military wings in Syria and Iraq opposed the creation of a pan-Arab state, whereas al-Shufi and al-Sadi supported it. Aflaq officially supported it, but privately opposed it because he was afraid al-Sadi would challenge his position as secretary-general of the National Command of the Ba'ath Party, the leader of the international Ba'athist movement.
Bilateral union.
Both Syria and Iraq were under Ba'athist rule in 1963. When President Arif visited Syria on a state visit, <a href="Sami%20al-Jundi">Sami al-Jundi</a>, a Syrian cabinet minister, proposed the creation of a <a href="Bilateralism">bilateral</a> union between the two countries. Both Arif and <a href="Amin%20al-Hafiz">Amin al-Hafiz</a>, <a href="President%20of%20Syria">President of Syria</a>, supported the idea. al-Jundi was given the task of setting up a committee to begin establishing the union. al-Jundi selected al-Sadi as Iraq's chief representative in the committee in a bid to strengthen al-Sadi's position within the Ba'ath Party.
Work on the union continued with the signing of the Military Unity Charter which established the Higher Military Council, an organ which oversaw the integration and control over the Syrian and Iraqi military. Ammash, the Iraqi <a href="Ministry%20of%20Defence%20%28Iraq%29">Minister of Defence</a>, became the chairman of the Higher Military Council. The unified headquarters was in Syria. The establishment of the military union became evident on 20 October 1963, when Syrian soldiers were found fighting alongside the Iraqi military in <a href="Iraqi%20Kurdistan">Iraqi Kurdistan</a>. At this stage, both Iraqi and Syrian Ba'athists feared excluding Nasser from the union talks since he had a large following.
The Syrian state and its <a href="Arab%20Socialist%20Ba%27ath%20Party%20%E2%80%93%20Syria%20Region">Ba'ath Party</a> criticised the fall of al-Bakr's first government but relented when they discovered that some members of the Iraqi cabinet were Ba'ath Party members. However, the remaining Ba'athists were slowly removed from office. The <a href="National%20Council%20for%20the%20Revolutionary%20Command">Syrian Revolutionary Command Council</a> responded by <a href="Repeal">abrogating</a> the Military Unity Charter on 26 April 1964, ending the bilateral unification process between Iraq and Syria.
Underground: 1963–1968.
In the aftermath of the coup-led against the Ba'ath Party, al-Bakr became the party's dominant driving force and was elected secretary-general of the Regional Command in 1964. Saddam Hussein received full party membership and a seat in the Regional Command of the Iraqi Ba'ath Party because he was a close protege of al-Bakr. With al-Bakr's consent, Hussein initiated a drive to improve the party's internal security. In 1964, Hussein established the Jihaz Haneen, the party's secretive security apparatus, to act as a counterweight to the military officers in the party and to weaken the military's hold on the party.
Ba'athist Iraq: 1968–2003.
In contrast to the coup of 1963, the 1968 coup was led by civilian Ba'ath Party members. According to historian Con Coughlin, the President of Iraq <a href="Abdul%20Rahman%20Arif">Abdul Rahman Arif</a>, who had taken over from his brother, was a weak leader. Before the coup, Hussein, through the Jihaz Haneen, contacted several military officers who either supported the Ba'ath Party or wanted to use it as a vehicle to power. Some officers, such as <a href="Hardan%20al-Tikriti">Hardan al-Tikriti</a>, were already members of the party, while <a href="Abdul%20Razzak%20al-Naif">Abdul Razzak al-Naif</a>, the deputy head of military intelligence, and Colonel Ibrahim Daud, the commander of the <a href="Republican%20Guard%20%28Iraq%29">Republican Guard</a>, were neither party members nor sympathisers.
On 16 July 1968, al-Naif and Daud were summoned to the <a href="Radwaniyah%20Palace">Presidential Palace</a> by Arif, who asked them if they knew of an imminent coup against him. Both al-Naif and Daud denied knowledge of any coup. However, when the Ba'ath Party leadership obtained this information, they quickly convened a meeting at al-Bakr's house. The coup had to be initiated as quickly as possible, even if they had to concede to give al-Naif and Daud the posts of Prime Minister and Defence Minister, respectively. Hussein said at the meeting, "I am aware that the two officers have been imposed on us and that they want to stab the party in the back in the service of some interest or other, but we have no choice. We should collaborate with them and liquidate immediately during, or after, the revolution. And I volunteer to carry out the task".
The <a href="17%20July%20Revolution">17 July Revolution</a> was a military coup, not a popular revolt against the incumbent government. According to Coughlin, compared to the coups of 1958 and 1963, the 1968 coup was a "relatively civil affair". The coup begun in the early morning of 17 July, when the military and Ba'ath Party <a href="activism">activists</a> seized several key positions in Baghdad, such as the headquarters of the Ministry of Defence, television and radio stations and the electricity station. All the city's bridges were captured, all telephone lines were cut and at exactly 03:00, the order was given to march on the Presidential Palace. President Arif was asleep and had no control over the situation. al-Bakr masterminded the plot, but Hussein and <a href="Saleh%20Omar%20al-Ali">Saleh Omar al-Ali</a> led operations on the ground. A power struggle began between the Ba'ath Party led by al-Naif and the military led by Daud, which al-Bakr had anticipated and planned. Daud lost his ministership during an official visit to <a href="Jordan">Jordan</a>, while al-Naif was exiled after Hussein threatened him and his family with death.
At the time of the 1968 coup, only 5,000 people were members; by the late 1970s, membership had increased to 1.2 million. In 1974, the Iraqi Ba'athists formed the <a href="National%20Progressive%20Front%20%28Iraq%29">National Progressive Front</a> to broaden support for the government's initiatives. Wrangling within the party continued, and the government periodically purged its <a href="dissident">dissident</a> members, including <a href="Fuad%20al-Rikabi">Fuad al-Rikabi</a>, the party's first secretary-general of the Regional Command. Emerging as the party strongman, Hussein used his growing power to push al-Bakr aside in 1979 and ruled Iraq until the <a href="2003%20Invasion%20of%20Iraq">2003 Invasion of Iraq</a>.
Under al-Bakr's tenure, Iraq experienced its most dramatic and successful period of economic growth with its citizens enjoying standards of healthcare, housing, education and earnings comparable with those of European countries. Several major infrastructures were laid down to assist the country's growth, and the Iraqi oil industry was nationalised with help from the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>. <a href="Alexei%20Kosygin">Alexei Kosygin</a>, Chairman of the <a href="Council%20of%20Ministers%20%28Soviet%20Union%29">USSR Council of Ministers</a>, signed the bilateral Treaty of Friendship and Cooperation in 1972.
2003 invasion and new Iraqi government.
Downfall and de-Ba'athification.
In June 2003, the <a href="United%20States">U.S.</a>-led <a href="Coalition%20Provisional%20Authority">Coalition Provisional Authority</a> banned the Ba'ath Party, and banned all members of the party's top four tiers from the new government and from <a href="Public%20school%20%28government%20funded%29">public schools</a> and colleges, a move which some criticised for blocking too many experienced people from participating in the new government. Thousands were removed from their positions, including doctors, professors, school teachers and bureaucrats. Many teachers lost their jobs, causing protests and demonstrations at schools and universities.
Under the Ba'ath Party, one could not reach high positions in the government or in schools without becoming a party member. Membership was also a prerequisite for university admission. While many Ba'athists joined for ideological reasons, many more joined as a way to improve their options. After much pressure by the U.S., the policy of <a href="de-Ba%27athification">de-Ba'athification</a> was addressed by the Iraqi government in January 2008 in the highly controversial "Accountability and Justice Act," which was supposed to ease the policy, but which many feared would lead to further dismissals.
The new <a href="Constitution%20of%20Iraq">Constitution of Iraq</a>, approved by a <a href="referendum">referendum</a> on 15 October 2005, reaffirmed the Ba'ath Party ban, stating that "No entity or program, under any name, may adopt <a href="racism">racism</a>, <a href="terrorism">terrorism</a>, the calling of others <a href="infidel">infidel</a>s, <a href="ethnic%20cleansing">ethnic cleansing</a>, or incite, facilitate, glorify, promote, or justify thereto, especially the Saddamist Ba'ath in Iraq and its symbols, regardless of the name that it adopts. This may not be part of the political <a href="Pluralism%20%28political%20theory%29">pluralism</a> in Iraq."
Some or many of its members in the Iraqi Ba'ath Party who were purged and dismissed went on to join <a href="Al-Qaeda%20in%20Iraq">Al-Qaeda in Iraq</a> in which eventually morphed into the <a href="Islamic%20State%20of%20Iraq%20and%20the%20Levant">Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant</a>.
Saddam's death and party split: 2006–present.
On 31 December 2006, one day after <a href="Saddam%20Hussein">Saddam Hussein</a>'s execution by hanging, a previously unknown group called the Baghdad Citizens Gathering publicly issued a statement in <a href="Amman">Amman</a>, Jordan, at the <a href="Jordanian%20Arab%20Socialist%20Ba%27ath%20Party">Jordanian Regional Branch of the Ba'ath Party</a> endorsing <a href="Izzat%20Ibrahim%20al-Douri">Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri</a> as the new president of Iraq and the party's secretary-general following <a href="Execution%20of%20Saddam%20Hussein">Saddam's death</a>. The statement referred to Iraqis killed in the 1980–88 war with <a href="Iran">Iran</a>, the 1991 <a href="Gulf%20War">Gulf War</a> over Kuwait and the 13 years of sanctions afterwards, and went on to say, "We vow to liberate our country from the heinous criminals, neo-<a href="Zionism">Zionists</a> and the <a href="Persian%20people">Persians</a> in order to restore Iraq's unity". The party's armed wing since al-Douri's ascension is the <a href="Army%20of%20the%20Men%20of%20the%20Naqshbandi%20Order">Army of the Men of the Naqshbandi Order</a>.
According to Abu Muhammad, a Ba'ath Party spokesman from al-Douri's faction, on the eve of Saddam's death, "Comrade Izzat has been leading the [Ba'ath] party's political and resistance factions since 2003, but it is a matter of <a href="Protocol%20%28politics%29">protocol</a> and internal regulation to appoint him officially as the party's secretary-general." Al-Douri was elected the party's secretary-general in early January.
Despite al-Douri's succession, another high ranking Ba'athist, <a href="Younis%20al-Ahmed">Younis al-Ahmed</a>, called for a General Conference of the Iraqi Ba'ath party in Syria to elect a new leadership (the faction's armed wing is <a href="The%20Return%20%28guerilla%20organization%29">The Return</a>). This move caused a significant amount of controversy within the party, with al-Douri issuing a statement criticizing Syria for what al-Douri claimed was an American-supported attempt to undermine the Iraqi Ba'ath party, although this statement was later downplayed. The conference elected al-Ahmed as secretary-general, and al-Ahmed issued an order expelling al-Douri from the party, resulting in al-Douri issuing a counter order expelling al-Ahmed and 150 other party members. These events led to the existence, in effect, of two Iraqi Ba'ath Parties: the main party led by al-Douri, and a <a href="The%20Return%20%28guerrilla%20organization%29">splinter party</a> led by al-Ahmed.
al-Ahmed's Ba'ath Party is based in Syria. It is believed to contain most of the remaining leading party figures who were not arrested or executed, including Mezher Motni Awad, To'ma Di'aiyef Getan, Jabbar Haddoosh, Sajer Zubair, and Nihad alDulaimi. In contrast to al-Douri's group, al-Ahmad's faction has had success in recruiting Shi'as to the party. While al-Ahmed and the faction's senior leaders are Sunnis, there are many Shiites who are working in the organization's middle level. Upon his election as leader, an al-Ahmed's faction statement said he was "of Shia origins and coming from Shia areas in <a href="Nineveh">Nineveh</a> governorate". In contrast to al-Ahmed, al-Douri has stuck to a more conservative policy, recruiting members from a largely Sunni-dominated areas.
It could be said that al-Ahmed has returned to the Ba'ath Party's original ideology of secular pan-Arab nationalism which, in many cases, has proven successful in Iraq's Shi'a dominated southern provinces. However, despite his attempts, al-Ahmed has failed in his goal to overthrow al-Douri. Al-Douri's faction is the largest and the most active on the Internet, and the large majority of Ba'athist websites are aligned to al-Douri. Another failure is that al-Ahmed's faction, which is based in Syria, does not have exclusive Syrian support and, considering that it is based in Syria, the party is susceptible to Syrian interference in its affairs. However, despite the differences between the al-Douri and al-Ahmed factions, both of them adhere to Ba'athist thought.
On 2 January 2012, the Organizations of Central <a href="Euphrates">Euphrates</a> and the South (OCES), believed to be headed by Hamed Manfi al-Karafi, issued a statement condemning <a href="sectarianism">sectarianism</a> within the party, specifically criticizing al-Douri's faction. The OCES condemned the leadership's decision of creating a primary Sunni leadership and a reserve Shiite leadership.
This decision by the al-Douri faction leadership was a response to complaints by Ba'athist organizations in Shiite-dominated areas on what they considered policy errors which led to marginalization and exclusion of Shiite members. The OCES rejected the decision, and considered them illegitimate. In its statement, the OCES stated that "the failure to implement [its] decisions is considered a rebellion against legitimate authority [...]" and "a conscious and explicit threat, and an attempt to impose a bitter reality through decisions that are tainted by sectarian and regional motivations." In its ending remarks, the OCES statement read "any connection or link with any member of the Iraqi branch leadership locally or abroad, while continuing organizational activities according to the Organizations of Central Euphrates and the South leadership's decisions that were reached last year based on prior understandings with the national leadership". Despite breaking with al-Douri's faction, al-Karafi's faction has not aligned itself with either al-Ahmed's faction or Resurrection and Renewal Movement, a third Ba'athist group.
al-Douri has been considered more of a symbol, but he doesn't actually hold that much power over the party. In a discussion with the American embassy in Amman, Jordan, in 2007, retired Lieutenant General Khalid al-Jibouri stated that he believed "a powerful shadow group of personnel [was] behind him who really constitute the operational leadership of his faction". He further noted that the party was modernizing, in the sense that it recognized it would be impossible to return to power alone, while, at the same time, it returned to its old, Ba'athist ideological roots. In another note, al-Jibouri noted that the Ba'ath Party had become a major enemy of <a href="al-Qaida%20in%20Iraq">al-Qaida in Iraq</a>.
In the wake of <a href="Muammar%20Gaddafi">Muammar Gaddafi</a>'s <a href="2011%20Libyan%20Civil%20War">downfall</a>, the new Libyan government sent documents to the Iraqi government which claimed that Ba'athists, with help from Gaddafi, were planning a coup. Because of the revelations, the Iraqi government initiated a purge of thousands of public officials. The purge triggered Sunni protests, with many calling for Sunni <a href="autonomy">autonomy</a> within Iraq. Surprisingly to outside observers, al-Douri's Ba'ath party opposed Sunni autonomy and, in a statement, referred to it as "a dangerous plan to divide Iraq along sectarian lines." However this condemnation was mostly symbolic as Al-Douri's group participated in protests where calls for Sunni Autonomy were present and allied with groups that believed in and agitated for autonomy.
In July 2012, the Ba'ath Party published a videotaped speech of al-Douri, in which he condemned the existing government and American interference in Iraq. However, in a change of tone, al-Douri stated he wished to establish good relations with the United States when the <a href="United%20States%20Armed%20Forces">American forces</a> had been withdrawn and when the government had been toppled. As of 2013, it has been reported that al-Douri is living in the city of <a href="Mosul">Mosul</a>, having left Syria because of the <a href="Syrian%20civil%20war">ongoing civil war</a>. Many analysts are afraid that the Ba'ath Party has the potential power to initiate another civil war in Iraq because of al-Douri's popularity in localities with Sunni majorities.
Organization and structure.
Regional (central) level.
The Regional Command (RC) () was the Iraqi Regional Branch highest decision-making organ. Throughout its history, the RC has normally had 19-21 members. When in power, the Directorate of Security Affairs was responsible for the security of the president and the senior members of the Regional Command. The Regional Congress was (in theory) the "<a href="de%20jure">de jure</a>" decision-making organ on <a href="Iraq">Iraq</a>i regional affairs when in session, but was (in practice) a tool in control of the Regional Command.
The Ba'ath Party had its own <a href="Secretariat%20%28administrative%20office%29">secretariat</a> (), through which every major decision in the country was channelled. According to Joseph Sassoon, the secretariat functioned as the "party's <a href="board%20of%20directors">board of directors</a>," overseeing the running of the party branches which, in turn, controlled and collected information about <a href="civilian">civilian</a> and <a href="military">military</a> life throughout the country. The secretariat had the power to propose marriages and, in certain cases, to approve and disapprove marriages for the sake of the party. At the 8th Regional Congress, the leadership laid emphasis on building "a strong and central national authority." The party leadership's response to the party's apparent lack of <a href="centralisation">centralisation</a> came with a <a href="Revolutionary%20Command%20Council%20%28Iraq%29">Revolutionary Command Council</a> resolution which stated that "all correspondence between state ministries and party organisations are to be sent through the party secretariat."
The head of the secretariat was the deputy director, who was the second in the <a href="order%20of%20precedence">order of precedence</a>. The office of director of the secretariat was the leading organ within the body. The secretariat had 11 departments: the Military and <a href="Weapon">Armaments</a> Department, <a href="Vocational%20school">Vocational Schools</a> Department, Courses Department, Finance Department, Organisational and Political Department, Party Affairs and Information Department, Personnel and Administrative Department, Technical Department, Information and Studies Department, Legal Department and the Audit Department. The only non-department under the direct responsibility of the secretariat was the Saddam Institute for the Study of the <a href="Quran">Qur'an</a>.
The functions and responsibilities of the secretariat were drawn up in a detailed manner. The Office of the President issued a directive to formulate its <a href="hierarchy">hierarchy</a>, and the functions of the sections and departments were clearly defined. The secretariat encompassed all party branches. This system led to the <a href="Bureaucracy">bureaucratisation</a> of the party, and decision-making was often cumbersome and inefficient. This inefficiency meant that Saddam could govern without fearing any rivals.
The Department for Organisational and Political Affairs (DOPA) was the most important department of the secretariat. It prepared material for discussion that the <a href="Secretary-General">secretary-general</a> (), the party's leader, personally ordered. The DOPA also was responsible for following up on political matters in party branches. One of DOPA's sections was responsible for gathering information for candidates for important positions within the party or the government. Some departments had a similar job to the DOPA section, and were responsible for admissions to the <a href="Military%20academy">military colleges</a>, institutions for higher education and the Saddam Institute for the Study of the Qur'an. The party sought to control these institutions so that no single opposition party could gain a foothold in them.
Lower levels.
Below the Regional Command were the bureau structures (), which would gather all party activities in a single geographic area into the responsibility of a single unit. Until 1989, there were six bureau structures in the country: in <a href="Baghdad">Baghdad</a>, Al-Forat, the centre, southern and northern Iraq, and one bureau for military affairs. By 2002, there were 17. Below the bureau structures was the branch (), which supervised the activities of the sections, divisions and cells (. Several of these organs were merged or split, and the number of branches had increased to 69 branches by 2002. The numbers of sections and divisions varied between provinces. As membership increased, new sections and divisions were established. In <a href="Maysan%20province">Maysan province</a>, the number of sections increased from five in 1989 to 20 in 2002, each section in turn having 93 divisions. By September 2002, there existed 4,468 party offices in the country, and there were 32,000 cells.
Security functions.
Nationally, the Ba'ath Party functioned as an institution acting as the eyes and ears of the government. During its rule, the party gained influence over the military, the government bureaucracy, labour, professional unions and, not least, the building of the <a href="cult%20of%20personality">cult of personality</a> of Saddam. From the 1990s until the fall of the Ba'ath Party in 2003, it became involved in the handling of food distribution, the pursuing and apprehension of military <a href="desertion">deserters</a> and, by the end, it was responsible for the preparations for the <a href="2003%20invasion%20of%20Iraq">2003 invasion of Iraq</a>. Branches and sections enjoyed powers similar to those of the police in the <a href="Western%20culture">West</a>. Outside of Baghdad, they were "legally authorised to incarcerate suspects using <a href="Extrajudicial%20punishment">Extrajudicial procedures</a>".
One of the party's most important functions was gathering information about its opponents. In <a href="Iraqi%20Kurdistan">Northern Iraq</a>, the Ba'ath gathered information about the <a href="Kurdish%20Democratic%20Party">Kurdish Democratic Party</a> by tracking their activities among the local population. They tried to recruit members from <a href="Kurdish%20people">Kurd</a>-dominated areas through supplying food or a <a href="literacy">literacy</a> campaign. During the drive to Arabise <a href="Iraqi%20Kurdistan">Kurdistan</a>, the party resettled several hundred loyal party officials there to strengthen the party in the area. Kurds who had moved from Kurdistan would, in most instances, not be allowed back unless they were loyal Ba'ath Party members. The Military and Armament Department was responsible for coordinating the distribution of arms to party officials.
Management.
Discipline.
The Ba'ath Party instilled party <a href="discipline">discipline</a> in its members. According to a statement in the <a href="Revolutionary%20Command%20Council%20%28Iraq%29">Revolutionary Command Council</a> (RCC), "Party members are expected to inspire others by their exemplary behavior, sense of discipline, political consciousness, and willingness to sacrifice themselves in the interests of the Party and state." Saddam was a great believer in discipline, and believed that lack of discipline and organisation were behind any failure. In accordance with this view, the party issued a myriad of rules and regulations to combat laziness, <a href="corruption">corruption</a> and abuses of power. Members found breaching the party code were either demoted or expelled from the party.
Finances.
The Ba'ath Party was supported financially by the RCC, the highest executive and legislative body of government. Members were required to pays fees commensurate with their ranks. For instance, a supporting member would pay 25 Iraqi <a href="dinar">dinar</a> for membership, while a branch member would pay 3,000 Iraqi dinars. Fees were important in the party's balance sheet. The central party leadership often emphasised the importance of members' financial abilities. The leadership encouraged members to contribute more to party finances. According to Jawad Hashim, a former Minister of Planning and the RCC Economic Advisor, Saddam gave the Ba'ath Party the five percent of Iraqi oil revenues, which were previously owned by the Gulbenkin Foundation. Saddam's reasoning was that, if a counter-<a href="Coup%20d%27%C3%A9tat">coup</a> took place and the Ba'ath Party was forced from power, as had been the case in <a href="November%201963%20Iraqi%20coup%20d%27%C3%A9tat">November 1963</a>, the party needed financial security so that it could reclaim power. By Hasim's estimates, the Ba'ath Party had accumulated in external revenues by 1989.
Membership.
When the party came to power in 1968 in the <a href="17%20July%20Revolution">17 July Revolution</a>, it was determined to increase party membership so that it could compete with <a href="ideology">ideological</a> opponents such as the <a href="Iraqi%20Communist%20Party">Iraqi Communist Party</a>. Saddam had a clear plan, and on 25 February 1976 he said, "It should be our ambition to make all Iraqis in the country Ba'athists in membership and belief or in the latter only." This is contrary to his statements in the 1990s, when increasing membership was more important than recruiting members who adhered to Ba'athist ideology.
Like most parties, the Ba'ath membership was organised in a hierarchical manner. The head of a branch, division or section was the secretary-general, who was responsible to the secretariat. At the bottom was sympathiser, a member seeking to climb the party ranks with the status of active members, which could take five to 10 years. In certain provinces, "national activity" was the status given to the lowest level of the hierarchy. Where this level existed, it could take two to three years to climb up to the rank of sympathiser. The report to the 10th National Congress stated that "It is not sufficient for a member just to believe in the idea of the party, but what is required is total commitment and not simply a political affiliation."
